title: Hot Potato Debate
desc: Students pass a ball while music plays. When it stops, the holder must instantly give an argument.
steps: Play upbeat music while students pass a ball or object around the circle.
Stop the music randomly.
Display a controversial but lighthearted topic (e.g., 'Cats are better than dogs').
The student holding the object must immediately give one argument FOR or AGAINST.
Resume music immediately to keep energy high.
variation: Use 'Truth or Dare' questions instead of debate topics for a fun ice-breaker.

title: Silent Comic Strip
materials: Printed comic strips with empty speech bubbles
desc: Students fill in empty speech bubbles of a comic strip to create a coherent story silently.
steps: Distribute a comic strip with empty speech bubbles to each student.
Set a timer for 10 minutes of absolute silence.
Students must write dialogue that makes sense narratively.
After time is up, students swap comics and read their partner's story.
variation: Cut the comic panels out separately and have students rearrange them before writing.

title: Board Race
desc: Two teams relay race to the board to write words related to a topic.
steps: Divide class into two teams standing in lines.
Give the first student in each line a marker.
Shout a category (e.g., 'Animals').
Students run to the board, write one word, run back, and pass the marker.
The team with the most correct words after 2 minutes wins.
variation: Restrict words to a specific letter (e.g., Animals starting with 'B'). For ages 3-6, have them touch flashcards on the board instead of writing.

title: Two Truths & A Lie
desc: Students spot the lie among three statements about their peers.
steps: Give students 3 minutes to write down two true facts and one lie about themselves.
In small groups, one student reads their three statements.
The group can ask 3 follow-up questions to try and catch them out.
The group votes on which statement is the lie.
variation: Teacher plays first to model the activity and build rapport.

title: Running Dictation
desc: A memory and running game where students dictate texts found on walls.
steps: Stick short texts on walls outside the classroom or in the hallway.
Pair students: one 'Runner' and one 'Scribe'.
Runner runs to the text, memorizes a sentence, runs back, and dictates it.
Scribe writes it down. If they forget, the Runner must go back.
First pair to write the text correctly wins.
variation: Swap roles halfway through the text.

title: Vocab Pictionary
desc: Drawing vocabulary words for teammates to guess.
steps: Prepare a stack of cards with vocabulary words.
One student comes to the front, picks a card.
They have 60 seconds to draw the word on the board without speaking or writing letters.
Their team must guess the word.
variation: Use 'Claymation' style where they mold the word with playdough instead of drawing.

title: Sentence Surgery
desc: Physical rearrangement of jumbled sentence parts.
steps: Prepare envelopes containing strips of paper with words from a sentence.
Give an envelope to each pair of students.
Students dump the words and rearrange them physically to form a correct sentence.
They raise their hand when they think they have 'healed' the sentence.
variation: Include one 'distractor' word that doesn't belong in the sentence.

title: Back-to-Back Drawing
desc: Describing an image to a partner who cannot see it.
steps: Pairs sit in chairs back-to-back.
Student A is given a simple picture/diagram.
Student B has a blank paper and pencil.
Student A describes the image using shapes and prepositions (e.g., 'Draw a square in the center').
Compare the drawing with the original.
variation: Use Tangram puzzles instead of drawing for a tactile version.

title: Gallery Walk
desc: Peer review activity walking around the classroom.
steps: Post student work (essays, posters, etc.) on the classroom walls.
Give every student a pack of sticky notes.
Play calm music as students walk around 'viewing the gallery'.
Students leave one compliment and one question on a sticky note for each piece.
variation: Use different colored sticky notes for different types of feedback (e.g., Pink for praise, Green for growth).

title: This or That
desc: Students choose between two options by moving to different sides of the room, explaining their choice.
steps: Ask students to stand in the middle of the room.
Present two related words or concepts (e.g., 'Apples or Bananas', or 'Summer or Winter').
Designate the left side of the room for option A and the right side for option B.
Students run to the side they prefer.
Ask random students to justify their choice in English.
variation: For older students, make the prompts moral dilemmas or debatable topics.

title: Devil's Advocate
desc: Students are forced to argue in favor of a statement they actually disagree with.
steps: Write a controversial statement on the board.
Ask students who agrees and who disagrees.
Pair up students and force them to argue the opposite of their actual belief.
Give them 5 minutes to prepare arguments.
Have pairs present their arguments to the class.
variation: Turn it into a formal mini-debate with a strict 1-minute timer for opening statements and rebuttals.

title: Stop the Bus
desc: A fast-paced vocabulary game where teams race to fill categories starting with a specific letter.
steps: Divide the class into small teams.
Draw a table on the board with 5 categories (e.g., Animal, Food, Country, Verb, Color).
Call out a random letter of the alphabet.
Teams race to write one word for each category starting with that letter.
The first team to finish yells 'Stop the Bus!'.
Review the answers. If all are correct, they win the round.
variation: Make the categories grammar-focused, like 'Irregular Verb', 'Adjective', 'Preposition'.

title: Kim's Game
desc: A classic memory game to test and reinforce new vocabulary items.
steps: Place 10-15 familiar vocabulary items on a tray.
Let the students study the tray in silence for 1 minute.
Cover the tray with a cloth.
Students must write down (or say aloud for ages 3-6) as many objects as they can remember.
Uncover the tray and count the correct answers.
variation: Instead of covering everything, secretly remove one item while their eyes are closed and ask 'What's missing?'
